awd_titl_txt: CDMR: Tuning the Mechanical Properties of Ordered Supramolecular Polymers and Their Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
PART1: NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Supramolecular polymers represent a new generation of polymeric materials, offering advantageous properties in processing, self-healing, and recycling, and have important technological applications as both electronically and biological active materials. Possessing the fundamental knowledge that would enable the precise tuning of the mechanical properties at the polymer molecular and network level could lead to a significant shift in the way that supramolecular materials are designed. This project is in the general area of Computationally and Data-Driven Materials Research (CDMR).  It aims to develop an in-depth understanding of the various factors that affect the cooperative association of small molecular building units into supramolecular polymers, and to use the knowledge gained to achieve precise control over the mechanical properties of individual polymers as well as their 3D networks. A combined use of experimental and computational methodologies will help elucidate the key features of these building units for precise control over the mechanical properties of the resulting supramolecular polymers. Prediction of the pathway of self-assembly is proposed with molecular modeling at multiple length-scales. Knowledge generated from this work will impact the development of advanced materials for applications in organic electronics, where the polymer length and inter-polymer associations are important, and in regenerative medicine, which requires biologically active hydrogels with defined stiffness. The two PIs bring complementary experimental and theoretical/computational expertise to this integrated project and are committed to providing a broad educational experience at all levels.



PART 2: TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The formation of ordered supramolecular polymers (SPs), utilizing small molecular building units that can assemble into highly ordered and discrete one-dimensional (1D) nanostructures, has led to the development of functional supramolecular materials. This project is in the general area of Computationally and Data-Driven Materials Research (CDMR) and is focused on in-depth understanding of the various factors that affect the cooperative association of small molecular building units.  It aims to design and synthesize a series of small-molecule mikto-arm star building units (MASBUs) possessing three distinct functional arms (two hydrophobic and one hydrophilic), and to elucidate the key molecular design features that define their growth kinetics and eventual mechanical properties of ordered SPs. A combined experimental and computational approach with an active feedback mechanism will be applied to correlate the sequential variation of each arm with the mechanical properties (persistence length, contour length, bundling) of the resulting SPs and their networks. Specifically, Objectives 1 and 2 will focus on the synthesis and study of MASBUs possessing isomeric hydrocarbons and pi-conjugated segments, respectively, aiming to determine the relationship between the internal packing order and the persistence length. Objective 3 aims to establish a correlation between the growth kinetics and the contour length by varying the strength of associative interactions within a peptide segment capable of forming intermolecular hydrogen bonding. Objective 4 will attempt to identify the key factors that determine the bulk mechanical properties of the supramolecular networks formed by the assembled SPs, in particular looking at the effect of the persistence and contour length and also the SP bundling.  A successful outcome will lead to significant advances in our fundamental knowledge of structure-property relationships in ordered SP systems, and could have a substantial impact on the creation of supramolecular materials.   The two PIs bring complementary experimental and theoretical/computational expertise to this integrated project and are committed to providing a broad educational experience at all levels.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The spontaneous, cooperative association of small molecular building units into discrete one-dimensional nanostructures with a high degree of internal order provides an effective means to construct ordered Supramolecular Polymers (SP) of varying properties. The non-covalent and living nature of such SPs provide unique properties for use as both electronically or biologically active materials, but at the same time it leads to relatively less defined features. This collaborative proposal has helped create an in-depth understanding of thermodynamic and kinetic factors that affect the cooperative association of small molecular building units into SPs. 

The unaddressed challenges in the fundamental SP design are concerned with exerting fine control over a SP’s persistence length, contour length, and inter-polymer interactions. We believe all these parameters can be traced back to the design of the monomeric unit, offering the possibility for fine-tuning through a simple change in molecular structure. At the individual SP level, the type and strength of the monomer interactions, as well as the packing order amongst them, will determine the persistence and contour lengths. At the supramolecular network level, the inter-polymer interactions will be largely governed by the surface chemistry and orientation of the individual polymers, with the mechanical properties being influenced by the persistence and contour lengths that determine how much conformational freedom is afforded to the polymers.

Our collaborative research has provided important insight into the fundamental design of ordered supramolecular polymers. We designed and synthesized a group of structural isomers of mikto-arm star building units (MASBUs), and investigated their self-assembly into supramolecular polymers. In this particular MASBU design, the packing requirements of the chosen isomeric hydrocarbons within the supramolecular polymers are dictated by their atomic arrangements at the molecular and intermolecular levels. Atomistic molecular dynamics simulations from the Loverde lab suggest that this design strategy can subtly alter the molecular packing at the interface between the peptide domain and the hydrophobic core of the supramolecular assemblies, without changing both the filament width and morphology. Our experimental results from wide-angle X-ray scattering confirmed that alterations to the intermolecular packing at the interface impact the strength and degree of hydrogen bonding within the peptide domains. This subtle difference in the isomeric hydrocarbon design and their consequent packing difference led to variations in the persistence length of the individual supramolecular filaments.

Unlike the chain-growth polymerization that can be well controlled by using a catalyst or initiator, little is known about how to use initiator to control/tune a supramolecular polymerization process. We discovered that a small hydrophobic molecule can be used as an effective initiator to induce the supramolecular polymerization of a peptide conjugate. We found that the peptide monomers alone in water self-assemble into spherical micelles, but in the presence of the added initiator, undergo a supramolecular polymerization process to form filamentous assemblies. Increasing the ratio of initiator to monomer expedites the polymerization kinetic process. These findings provide an early example of initiator-controlled supramolecular polymerization. 

This NSF grant enabled us to train a number of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows. Our team also offered lectures and demonstrations on supramolecular assembly to high school students. We recruited and trained high school teacher and undergraduate students in the subject of supramolecular polymers by providing hands-on research experiences. All the meaningful research results generated from this project are disseminated through peer-reviewed papers and research presentations in professional conferences.

 


Last Modified: 04/06/2020
Modified by: Honggang Cui
